For more than 30 years, anyone who's spent even one night in the Clinch County Jail in southeast Georgia had to pay for their room and board.
Even if the charges against you were dropped or you were acquitted, the fee still had to be paid.

John Sepulvado, of member station WUSF, reports.
For almost nine months, Willie Williams sat in the Clinch County Jail waiting to stand trial for rape.
Those charges have been dropped and Williams is back at work driving a forklift.
He says the absolute worst thing about the whole ordeal has to be the meals at the jail.
Williams says breakfast, every day, was powered eggs, half a wiener, and cold grits.
And we didn't get no lunch.
And supper, a lady named Lauramell(ph) cooked supper.
You can't eat it.
It ain't worth eating it.
For this bad food, Williams was charged $18 a day.
His total for room and board came to $4,608.
When he was released, Williams says a Clinch County jailer forced him to sign a promissory note stating that he would pay the money or end up back in jail.
And Williams was not alone.
For 30 years, the sheriff in Clinch County had been charging room and board fees to all inmates that spent at least one night in jail.
If I hadn't paid for it, you know, they said they was going to lock him back up if I didn't pay for it.

I had to make it--make efforts to make sure I paid that money on time.

His lawyer is Richard Strickland.
The sheriff is solely responsible for the operation of the jail under Georgia law.
